title: The Old Dragoons of 1850

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of bronze with black patina.

artist_display:
Frederic Remington (American, 1861–1909)
Cast by Roman Bronze Works (American, early 20th century)
description: The Old Dragoons of 1850 is another feat of Frederic Remington’s technical achievement. Stretching, twisting men and horses move at top speed, depicted by Remington in an arrested moment in time. The complex sculpture suggests the chaos of eyewitness observation, yet it also achieves the choreographed monumentality and unity of synthetic composition. Remington designed his three-dimensional works after the drawings and photographs he made on his trips to the West, and the ability to freeze motion photographically undoubtedly fed the force and dynamism of his sculpture.
inscriptions:
Inscribed on rear of base: "Roman Bronze Works / N.Y."
Inscribed left side of base: "Copyright / Frederic Remington"
publication_history: “Complete List of Accessions, February 25 to March 25, 1907,” Bulletin of the Metropolitan Museum of Art 2, 4 (April 1907), 74–75. Michael Edward Shapiro, Cast and Recast: The Sculpture of Frederic Remington (Washington DC: The Smithsonian Institution Press, 1981), 107. Mitchell Museum, George F. Harding Museum: Medieval and Renaissance Armor and Weapons, Remington Paintings, Bronzes and Drawings, (Mt. Vernon, IL: Mitchell Museum, 1981), 19, cat. 552. Charles Leroux, “Remington Legacy Rounded up for Art Institute Show,” Chicago Tribune, September 3, 1982, C3. Michael D. Greenbaum, Icons of the West: Frederic Remington's Sculpture (Ogdensburg, NY: Frederic Remington Art Museum, 1996), 189. Lauretta Dimmick, Donna J. Hassler, and Thayer Tolles, American Sculpture in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, ed. Thayer Tolles (New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1999), 386, 388. Judith A. Barter, Window on the West: Chicago and the Art of the New Frontier, 1890–1940, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago; New York and Manchester, VT: Hudson Hills Press, 2003), 88, 89, 97, 99, 169, 183, cat. 84, fig. 10.
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, Paintings, and Bronzes by Frederic Remington Lent by the George F. Harding Museum, June 21–Oct. 10, 1969, no cat. Mitchell Museum, Mt. Vernon, Illinois, George F. Harding Museum: Medieval and Renaissance Armor and Weapons, Remington Paintings, Bronzes and Drawings, Dec. 5, 1981–Jan. 31, 1982, cat. 552. Art Institute of Chicago, Frederic Remington: Painting and Sculpture from the George F. Harding Collection, Sept. 1, 1982–Oct. 11 1982, no cat. Art Institute of Chicago, Window on the West: Chicago and the Art of the New Frontier, 1890–1940, June 28–Oct. 13, 2003, cat. 84.
provenance_text: The artist, modeled 1905, cast 1906–07 [email from Thayer Tolles, Metropolitan Museum of Art curator, in curatorial file]; sold to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, March 1907 [Bulletin of the Metropolitan Museum of Art April 1907]; given back to the artist, c. September 1907 [according to Tolles 1999, the artist swapped it for another 1907 cast]. Tiffany and Co., New York, by March 9, 1922 [according to Greenbaum 1996]; sold to George F. Harding, Jr. (1868–1939), Chicago, March 9, 1922 [according to Barter 2003]; George F. Harding Museum, Chicago, no. 552, by 1939 [according to Leroux 1982]; transferred to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1982.
